comments.commentBody:
Paying down the debt is a false argument. It's the rich who buy the debt. Would you rather own debt and get paid interest on that debt or have the government tax you to pay down that debt?

The debt is only a surrogate for dismantling social security, medicare and medicaid - the social safety net. It has nothing whatever to do with debt, which exploded under the previous regime and has only increased in the last three years due to the depressed economy.

All the GOP and their patrons did was flush $1 TRILLION (and counting) into Iraq and Afghanistan. And, that was before counting the costs of oil going to $145/bbl in 2008.

On top of it all, the financial fallout of repealing Depression-era regulations cost the country $12 TRILLION in wealth.

Next brilliant observation?

Actually, Amanda, the Grand Bargain President Obama proposed was actually $4 trillion, and it was rejected by Reublicans over $1 of tax increases for every $4 of spending reduction.

Sounds like pretty good deficit reduction leverage to me and something you would have supported. Maybe you are an Obama supporter and don't even know it.

Yep.  The biggest taxpayers would be more cheerful about paying more if they thought the money would go to paying down the huge national debt.  The president had a chance to go out with that message, when his Simpson-Bowles panel proposed shared sacrifice to narrow the budget deficit.  But it involved spending cuts, which he didn't like.  So instead, he did nothing, and his allies went out with the 99% vs 1% theme.  So now we have payroll tax cuts for people who verge on wealthy, no end to them in sight (that's a "middle class tax increase"), and everyone can see where their tax dollars will go... to other people who have jobs, houses, and food on the table, just to share the wealth.  and there will have to be more tax increases on top of what's been proposed, because the deficit will still explode.  that's what happens when you have 99% business as usual during a time of fiscal crisis.

Actually, Haidt concluded that when it comes to economic justice, "some kids are in cahoots with the experimenters. They get to rig the marble machine before the rest of us have a chance to play with it." So at least he's aware of that.

Yet Haidt's general MO is to come up with a hypothesis that suits his personal prejudices and beliefs - which he describes as "centrist" - and then go looking for studies that support it.

In this case, he's ignoring other studies that show adults - not 3-year-olds - are much more empathic and altruistic than he implies. 3-year-olds cannot be stand-ins for adults. Observations of chimpanzees also buttress this aspect of primate behavior - altruism and empathy are situational. Chimps are far from being always greedy and selfish. As are humans, regardless of how they got their marbles. Of mammals that live in organized societies, empathy and altruism are the rule, not the exception - because the whole point of societies is survival. Haidt even points this out, but then abandons it to focus on the behavior of 3-year-olds with their marbles.

Media love Professor Haidt because he's TV-ready and well-spoken. He's ambitious and enjoying his 15 minutes of fame, which I sometimes suspect he would like to stretch to four years or so.
The problem with Dr. Haidt experiment is that Wall Street and Big banks do play with "marble" but bubble which create financial melt down in 2008, that he fail to explain.
The real life situation is that one kid owns the machine with the marbles and then pays the other kid with the marbles he withdraws from the machine to retrieve more marbles.

The causal relationships of the experiments do not apply in real economic and political life.  In addition the experiment is not valid because in actual finance the game is rigged and  outcomes controlled behind an obscure curtain, not by cooperative instincts after output is positive.  The whole experiment is full of holes and bears little relationship to societal crises.
Not really
Ron Paul?

I'm just going to say what other commenters have in a little different form. The ratio of girls to boys will always be 50/50. Think of the problem this way. The first "generation" will be half boys and half girls. All of the couples that had a boy will now have a second child. Half of those children will be boys, half will be girls. Now the couples with two boys will have another child. This third "generation" will also be half boys and half girls. And so on.

The only way to adjust the ratio is to invent a device that can identify and separate out sperm with XX chromosones, and then use artificial insemination!
A famine is more likely...

1. We aren't bankrupt. Really, we aren't. To whom do we owe the money? We control our own currency. If you think we are in hock to foreign governments, you are simply wrong.

2. Did you just read the first paragraph? The post is about far more than Obama.

Michelle Rhee is wrong. There is no way our economy is going to create 500,000 jobs every month, twelve months a year, for the next twenty years. At the peak of the dotcom frenzy, we were creating only 250,000 jobs a month.

Good points! Not to be Paranoid or anything, but... what are the 250 private, hidden detention camps around the US for? Illegal immigrants? And Occupiers??? And.... dissenters....

And, allowing the military to detain citizens without cause and to be held without charges and indefinitely....

And, allowing drones to monitor citizens...

Kicking the anthills of the 1% is a guarantee that those detention camps are to be filled.

Arm yourselves with GPS implants so your folks can track you. Gather within local support groups.

When the Moneyed Interests get scared they get mean, they play rough.

Witness the genocide, legalized, against the early Native Americans. Witness the bloody battles and anti-labor laws corruptly passed against the early labor unions in the US. Witness the slavery and anti- civil rights cruelties. Witness the current anit-immigrant persecutions of the right wingers and exploitations of their labors by Businesses.

The US is built on violence and aggression. Even some of the current comments on this article allude to "revolution", "guillotines", angry mobs with torches and sticks. John Wayne and the "wipe 'em out" movie heros are still alive and well in our American psyche.

"Let us not become the evil we abhor...."

Isn't that the truth! What audacity this dude has. I was very upset that Obama brought this crony capitalist on in the first place, and in fact, that move alone may move me to vote for someone or something else. I am hoping Nader is back again.

>And end Obama's wars in the Middle East, some of which he inherited from Bush Jr.

Actually, he inherited all of them Bush Jr.
I am a a Ph.D., where do I pick up my share of the bowl from which the rich eat?

Your comment would be valid if jobs were available for everyone who wanted one, people would never grow old and would be able to work well into their 80's, and sickness and disease no longer existed! Also, if children were universally able to absorb every bit of education provided them and everyone learned at exactly the same pace and to the same degree!

In short, yes.  It will take an emergency of epic proportions to move the American people beyond the rut they are stuck in.  Currently, most Americans still believe they have the best healthcare system in the world and that Democratic Socialism of the sort practiced in Europe is evil creeping Communism.  Although nothing could be further from the truth, it will take an earthquake of American public opinion to change the course of history and curtail our 'race to the bottom' of the economic and labor markets en masse.  I am not betting that America will be victorious in its efforts to remain free of the oligarchy and mainly middle class.

The problem, of course, is that the French Revolution was not a "reform," and an awful lot of lives of the innocent paid for the   excesses of the monarchy...in our case, I fear for our democratic republic...
I don't think "they" care about American consumers. The rest of the world will buy what little we export. These companies will then be American in name only.
By Jove I think you've got it.

We've been following Friedman's trickle-down economic theory for 30 years and and are now dealing with the nightmarish results.  When Friedman talked about 'personal and economic liberty,' he was apparently referring only to the top 1%.
Some of which he inherited?  Try ALL!

I'm 55 and I share the sentiment.
You forgot to add one thing, namely that a communist-run capitalist system in China is about to knock off this communist paradise for capitalists as the #1 economy in the world.

As for AIDS, nahhh, they won't cure it. There's no economic incentive to cure it, what with so much investment tied up in patented drugs to maintain people sick but alive.

America has come to a crossroads, it has to decide whether to become a real country and develop as such or continue to operate like a business, inevitably collapsing of its own entropy.
Regulation of derivatives: yes. Glass-Steagal: no. Canada has the total opposite of G-S and guess how many banks failed here? 0

Are you really Doctor Wu?
Or are you really just a shadow
Of the man that I once knew?

It is not the pure capitalist system that is being questioned. It is the system of economic feudalism, political corruption and unfair taxation (yes, the so-called progressive tax is anything but) that has warped the capitalist system.
Well, I like this article, and I'm a true conservative and nationalist.

What everybody fails to see as the root cause of climate chnage and unsustainability - unchecked global population growth. Stop procreating like animals, for no rhyme, reason, and without the financial means to keep your children   healthy, sate, safe,  and educated, and the Earth will become sustainable. 5 billion people, no more - this is the magic number for the earth. Stop this procreational madness and stop raping the Earth, or else you'll wind up with strictly enforced eugenics 50 years down the road.
